prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: musculoskeletal diseases and cognitive impairments in patients lead todifficulties in movement as well as negative effects on their psychologicalhealth. clinical gait analysis, a vital tool for early diagnosis and treatment,traditionally relies on expensive optical motion capture systems. recentadvances in computer vision and deep learning have opened the door to moreaccessible and cost-effective alternatives. this paper introduces a novelspatio-temporal transformer network to estimate critical gait parameters fromrgb videos captured by a single-view camera. empirical evaluations on a publicdataset of cerebral palsy patients indicate that the proposed frameworksurpasses current state-of-the-art approaches and show significant improvementsin predicting general gait parameters (including walking speed, gait deviationindex - gdi, and knee flexion angle at maximum extension), while utilizingfewer parameters and alleviating the need for manual feature extraction.
stories: The presence of musculoskeletal diseases and cognitive impairments in individuals can result in mobility issues and have adverse effects on their psychological well-being. Clinical gait analysis, which is crucial for early detection and treatment, typically uses costly optical motion capture systems. However, recent developments in computer vision and deep learning have made more affordable and accessible alternatives possible. This paper presents a new spatio-temporal transformer network that can estimate essential gait parameters from RGB videos taken with a single-view camera. Evaluations on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients suggest that this framework outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, showing significant improvements in predicting general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Additionally, the proposed method uses fewer parameters and eliminates the need for manual feature extraction.

Musculoskeletal diseases and cognitive problems in people can lead to issues with mobility and negatively impact their psychological health. It is essential to detect and treat these issues early, and clinical gait analysis is a crucial tool for this. However, this typically requires expensive optical motion capture systems. New advancements in computer vision and deep learning now make it possible to have cheaper and more accessible alternatives. This paper introduces a new spatio-temporal transformer network that can estimate vital gait parameters using RGB videos from a single-view camera. Tests on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients show that this method performs better than current state-of-the-art techniques, with significant improvements in predicting general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Furthermore, the proposed method uses fewer parameters and does not require manual feature extraction.

Musculoskeletal conditions and cognitive difficulties in individuals can result in mobility challenges and harm their psychological well-being. Early detection and treatment of these issues are vital, and clinical gait analysis is a key method for achieving this. Nevertheless, this usually involves costly optical motion capture systems. Recent developments in computer vision and deep learning now allow for more affordable and accessible options. This paper presents a novel spatio-temporal transformer network that can determine crucial gait parameters using RGB videos from a single-view camera. Experiments on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients indicate that this approach outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques, with substantial enhancements in estimating general gait parameters, including walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Additionally, the proposed method utilizes fewer parameters and does not need manual feature extraction.

Musculoskeletal disorders and cognitive impairments in people can lead to mobility issues and negatively affect their psychological health. It is essential to identify and address these problems early, and clinical gait analysis is a crucial approach for this. However, this often requires expensive optical motion capture systems. Thanks to advancements in computer vision and deep learning, there are now more cost-effective and accessible alternatives. This paper introduces a new spatio-temporal transformer network that can extract vital gait parameters using RGB videos from a single-view camera. Our method, tested on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients, surpasses existing state-of-the-art techniques, with significant improvements in estimating general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Furthermore, our approach uses fewer parameters and does not require manual feature extraction.

Musculoskeletal conditions and cognitive dysfunctions in individuals can result in issues with mobility and have negative impacts on their psychological well-being. Early detection and intervention of these issues are crucial, and clinical gait analysis is a key method for achieving this. Nevertheless, this often involves costly optical motion capture systems. With the progressions in computer vision and deep learning, there are now more affordable and accessible options. This paper presents a novel spatio-temporal transformer network that can derive essential gait parameters using RGB videos from a single-view camera. Our method, evaluated on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients, outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques, showing significant enhancements in estimating general gait parameters, including walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at peak extension. Additionally, our approach utilizes fewer parameters and does not need manual feature extraction.

The presence of musculoskeletal problems and cognitive impairments in people can lead to mobility issues and have adverse effects on their psychological health. It is vital to identify and address these issues early, and clinical gait analysis is a valuable tool for doing so. However, this typically requires expensive optical motion capture systems. Thanks to advancements in computer vision and deep learning, there are now more budget-friendly and accessible alternatives. This paper introduces a new spatio-temporal transformer network that can extract key gait parameters from RGB videos captured by a single-view camera. Our method, which we tested on a public dataset of cerebral palsy patients, outperforms existing state-of-the-art techniques, providing significant improvements in estimating general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at peak extension. Furthermore, our approach uses fewer parameters and does not require manual feature extraction.

The proposed method, tested on a publicly available dataset of cerebral palsy patients, outperformed existing state-of-the-art techniques in estimating general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Moreover, this approach uses fewer parameters and does not require manual feature extraction.

People with musculoskeletal and cognitive challenges may face challenges in movement and see a decline in their psychological well-being. It is crucial to identify and address these issues quickly, and clinical gait analysis can be helpful. But, motion capture systems can be expensive. Fortunately, advancements in computer vision and deep learning have led to more cost-effective and accessible alternatives. This paper introduces a new spatio-temporal transformer network that can extract vital gait parameters from RGB videos captured by a single-view camera. The proposed method, tested on a publicly available dataset of cerebral palsy patients, surpassed existing state-of-the-art techniques in estimating general gait parameters such as walking speed, gait deviation index (GDI), and knee flexion angle at maximum extension. Additionally, this approach uses fewer parameters and does not need manual feature extraction.
